Alan Dean wrote:
> Still don't like the WSDL-like nature of WADL though and this 
> still leaves open the question of how does a client discover 
> the mechanism to construct a URI. HTML specifies that anchor 
> tags contain opaque URIs and, yes, form tags can specify a 
> GET with an opaque base URI plus querystring parameters. But 
> this information is specified at the level of the 
> content-type format specification (as HTML does). That way, 
> the client knows that if they have been fed text/html or 
> application/xhtml+xml then these URI rules apply.
> 
> Following that logic, URI construction rules should be 
> specified by the content-type format specification. 

Can you give a reference for where HTML specifies anchor tags contain opaque
URI.  I didn't see that explicitly stated in the spec[1], though I could
have missed it.

That said, it seems to me to be a stretch to suggest that URI construction
rules should be done in content-type format specs and would encourage
recursive specification.
